fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability in Bamboo caused by a combination of issues in third-party libraries, including FreeMarker template library, used in Bamboo.

All versions of Bamboo from 3.0 up are affected.

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/MgFTE

The vulnerability is related to the [previously disclosed|http://freemarker.sourceforge.net/docs/versions_2_3_17.html#autoid_137] FreeMarker issue.
fields.summary: Arbitrary file disclosure vulnerability

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a code injection vulnerability in Bamboo caused by an underlying vulnerability in the third-party Webwork 2 framework. 

All versions of Bamboo from 3.0 up are affected.

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/MgFTE

This vulnerability is a variant of a [recently disclosed|https://www.sec-consult.com/files/20120104-0_Apache_Struts2_Multiple_Critical_Vulnerabilities.txt] Struts2 vulnerability.
fields.summary: Code injection vulnerability

fields.description:
If a plugin declares an {{<i18n>}} module that refers to a nonexistent properties bundle, Bamboo's implementation of I18nBean will throw the following exception every time you try to get any i18n string:
{code}
java.util.MissingResourceException: Can't find bundle for base name atlassian-plugin, locale en_US
    at java.util.ResourceBundle.throwMissingResourceException(ResourceBundle.java:1427)
    at java.util.ResourceBundle.getBundleImpl(ResourceBundle.java:1250)
    at java.util.ResourceBundle.getBundle(ResourceBundle.java:952)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.i18n.DefaultI18nBean.getPluginBundles(DefaultI18nBean.java:228)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.i18n.DefaultI18nBean.getPluginBundles(DefaultI18nBean.java:246)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.i18n.DefaultI18nBean.<init>(DefaultI18nBean.java:69)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.i18n.I18nBeanFactoryImpl.getI18nBean(I18nBeanFactoryImpl.java:59)
{code}

This happens not just for the plugin's own code, but any time any other plugin tries to get an i18n string, thus making Bamboo unusable. It shouldn't be so easy for a bad plugin to break the system. This appears to be Bamboo-specific; the other apps seem to ignore the error.

The simplest way to reproduce this is to create a plugin that doesn't have any i18n properties files at all, but that has this element in its atlassian-plugin.xml:
{code}
<resource type="i18n" name="i18n" location="nonexistent"/>
{code}

(Originally filed this as [UPM-1643|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/UPM-1643])
fields.summary: plugin with a bad i18n descriptor can make the system unusable

fields.description:
Branches can be manually configured, so there is no need to completely hide branches if the repository doesn't support autodetection. people may still want to add branches themselves.

So this issue involves
* For plans where the default repo doesn't support autodetection, remove the autodetect buttons and the option to configure then. Then add a message to the user that your repository doesn't support auto detection of branches
* the logic for this fix needs to check if the Repository implements BranchDetectionCapableRepository
* If we keep the code for the isBranchDetectionSupported in a common location that would be good as well so in case we want to relax this requirement and change the logic
* also hide the branches tab at plan level if plan has no branches yet
fields.summary: Hide Plan Branch for repositories that do not support autodetection
Branch detection should also work for Bitbucket and Github repository type

fields.description:
We recently cloned one of production servers in an effort to split our set of Bamboo projects/plans across two servers.

When the second Bamboo server was up and running with the imported data, we began the process of removing the plans that would no longer be run on the second server.

There were over 200 plans, with varying amounts of builds between them, up to 5500 builds in particular cases.

Everything right up until the Delete Plan Summary screen is fine. This is the screen where you confirm the plans/projects you wish to delete.
As soon as we confirmed, the browser just sat there spinning.
From the logs it was apparent that the plans for deletion had been queued in a deletion service, but that's not made apparent to the end user in the browser. Instead, the browser will arbitrarily timeout depending on local TCP timeout settings.
Furthermore, the deletion process seems incredibly slow, or possibly rate-limited. Roughly one job was being deleted a minute (pretty consistently even though consecutive plans might have 0 builds and 5000 builds).
Here's some sample output to illustrate that:
{noformat}
2012-01-12 15:42:21,935 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [DeletionServiceImpl] Deleting CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYQACON
2012-01-12 15:43:11,975 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting job results for CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYQACON
2012-01-12 15:43:12,723 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting chain results for CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYQACON
2012-01-12 15:43:12,724 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Build results data for CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYQACON removed, deleted 0 rows
2012-01-12 15:43:12,758 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [DeletionServiceImpl] Deleting CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYSUV
2012-01-12 15:44:03,196 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting job results for CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYSUV
2012-01-12 15:44:03,985 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting chain results for CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYSUV
2012-01-12 15:44:03,986 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Build results data for CON15-SILVER-DEPLOYSUV removed, deleted 584 rows
2012-01-12 15:44:04,017 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [DeletionServiceImpl] Deleting CON15-SILVER-WATS
2012-01-12 15:44:53,839 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting job results for CON15-SILVER-WATS
2012-01-12 15:44:54,603 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting chain results for CON15-SILVER-WATS
2012-01-12 15:44:54,604 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Build results data for CON15-SILVER-WATS removed, deleted 584 rows
2012-01-12 15:44:54,641 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [DeletionServiceImpl] Deleting CON15-SILVER-SELENIUM
2012-01-12 15:45:50,031 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting job results for CON15-SILVER-SELENIUM
2012-01-12 15:45:51,114 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting chain results for CON15-SILVER-SELENIUM
2012-01-12 15:45:51,115 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Build results data for CON15-SILVER-SELENIUM removed, deleted 113971 rows
2012-01-12 15:45:51,180 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [DeletionServiceImpl] Deleting CON15-SILVER-PUBLISH
2012-01-12 15:46:45,902 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting job results for CON15-SILVER-PUBLISH
2012-01-12 15:46:47,192 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Deleting chain results for CON15-SILVER-PUBLISH
2012-01-12 15:46:47,193 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-4] [BuildResultsSummaryHibernateDao] Build results data for CON15-SILVER-PUBLISH removed, deleted 132752 rows
{noformat}

The situation was also made confusing when doing deletes in batches. Lets say you've got 600 plans you want to remove, and you break this into 3 bulk-deletes of 200 plans.
Once the first set of 200 plans were confirmed for deletion, Bamboo will remove them from end-user visibility in the Bamboo UI, and remove them slowly in the background.
However, if you then bulk-delete a second batch of 200 plans, Bamboo will not hide them from end-user visibility until the first batch of 200 has completed. They should really be removed from visibility as soon as they are confirmed for deletion.

To sum up:
# Bulk deleting plans should allow the user to see the state of the deletion process once the deletes have been confirmed
## The delete confirmation screen should return immediately
## The remove plans landing screen should show details of what plans are currently in the queue for deletion along with an ETA for deletion completion
## Plans that have been marked for deletion but are not yet deleted should not appear in the "Remove Plans" screen after they've been confirmed for deletion. This happens when a plan has been queued for deletion but has not yet been removed.
# The performance of the delete process should be looked at, as it appears to be rate-limited 
# Once deletes have been confirmed, the plans should be removed from sight instantly, even if they will not be deleted in the background until a later time.
fields.summary: Improve bulk project/plan deletion / removal feedback + performance

fields.description: Available without authentication. This can be used to hide breakin attempts or fill the disk if no log rotation is in place.
fields.summary: LogToServer action lets anyone log messages to the server log

fields.description:
Currently the Bamboo dashboard shows information about the last build. When a new build starts, only the icon is changed to show that there is a build running.

Other information, like build number, when the build completed and the reason is still concerning the last completed build. Clicking on the build number takes me to the last completed build, not the current build. 

In addition, clicking on the progress icon takes me to the overview page, not the current build. This results in me always having to click 2 times to get to the latest build: either I make the mistake of clicking on the build number (only to find out I have to be somewhere else) or I click on the progress icon and I go to an overview page where I have to click on the current build to see detailed information.

I would like the Dashboard to show me real-time information about my current build. How long is it currently building, and what was the reason that triggered the current build. Also, I would like to go to the build detail of the current build with one single click.
fields.summary: Show current build on dashboard

fields.description:
Currently NEW_VALUE and OLD_VALUE don't have specific sizes set in our code.

If Oracle is being used as instance DB, and the variables values exceed 255 chars, the following is logged:
{code}
2012-01-09 11:23:58,958 ERROR [Thread-24] [JDBCExceptionReporter] ORA-12899: value too large for column "BAMBOO"."AUDIT_LOG"."NEW_VALUE" (actual: 257, maximum: 255)
{code}
Not having limits defined for the variables, make Oracle set them to 255. It is clear that 255 is not always enough.

The Error stops audit logging completely for the Plan/Job.
fields.summary: Some Audit Logs variables don't have a defined size, causing problems in Oracle

fields.description:
Have users that could be specified as QA, allowing them to "qualify" (or authorize) a build to be used. This would be nothing more than a flag that could be set for each build result by users with a "QA" privileged that would signify that a build has been approved by QA. 

The build summary page could display something to the effect of "Build Result Summary - Authorized" if QA has given their stamp of approval.

Also for areas that specify a list of build results for a project, authorized builds could be tagged with an astericks. Example:  #46* 

This idea has spawned from the way our company uses Bamboo. We build internal products that gets used throughout our company for other larger projects. We have our own internal builds that take place to our division, but when a project needs an "official" build with a QA stamped of approval, we are currently having our QA guys comment "Authorized" on a specific build result, and this can be very confusing at times.

I think a built in QA stamp of approval setup would be very beneficial to bamboo.
fields.summary: QA Result Qualification

{{webapp/WEB-INF/lib/atlassian-user-crowd-provider-3.3.3.jar}} is not avoiding the "NoClassDef" exceptions due to missing CrowdUserManager class as outlined in [Testing the Crowd Upgrade|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Upgrading+Bamboo+with+Crowd+to+Bamboo+3.2#UpgradingBamboowithCrowdtoBamboo32-TestingtheCrowdUpgrade]. 

Based on file size, it looks like 3.4.2 has no issues; however, I wanted to bring the bug up for 3.3.3 so that those that like to stay behind one or more releases can do so without too many bugs.

File size differences:

$ ls -al 3.3.2/webapp/WEB-INF/lib/atlassian-user-crowd-provider-3.3.3.jar

fields.description:
When a build is run, quarantined tests are stored in the build context. build runs, and then after it is run, the TestCaseResultImpl is saved. TestCaseResultImpl when created, accesses the current state of quarantine and not the state during build.

eg, if someone quarantines a test, runs a build, then unleashes the test before the build is finished, the incorrect state will be saved but the build will still pass.

Possible solutions are 
 * modify the TestCaseResultImpl to be created and use the saved quarantine state somehow
 * lock quarantine/unleash while a build is being run so that they cannot be modified unless the plan is not building
fields.summary: Fix problem with saved state of quarantined result not syncing with the actual state

Currently asterisks are not supported at the Artifacts "Location" field.

Since the "Copy Pattern" provides an example with asterisks, users are being induced to used them in the "Location" as well.

We need to validate the data provided at the "Location" field and make sure that asterisks will not be provided.
fields.summary: Add field data validation for the Artifact "Location" field

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Database version or log of upgrade tasks are not currently recorded within the Bamboo database and there is nothing to prevent Bamboo from starting / re-running / skipping upgrade tasks on an already upgraded (or not upgraded) database. This is sometimes very obvious or goes completely undetected until integrity issues present further down the track.

Problems typically present in upgrade and rollback situations where mismatches occur between the version stored on the filesystem vs the state / version of the current database.
h3. Suggested Solution
 * Bamboo version stored within the database that reflects the current database state aka 'Database schema version'
 * Audit log within database of upgrade tasks that have been run, with timestamp and status (e.g. success or failure). Ideally these log entries would be easily grouped with an identifier per upgrade attempt and show the detected version and the target version aka 'Database changelog table'
 * Proactive validation that would prevent Bamboo from starting if a mismatch is detected. This should be clearly displayed in the UI (as opposed to a generic fatal bootstrap error) with an explanation of the error. The concept of filesystem version vs database version and it's importance in our upgrade procedure isn't common knowledge to a lot of Bamboo Administrators.
fields.summary: Prevent Bamboo from running if database and home directory come from different build numbers.

fields.description:
Sometimes we receive tickets related to one thing, but after investigation we find out that the problem is related to a database corruption. In that case the support engineer has to manually clean the DB which takes a lot of time. Specifically, Buildresultsummary and Chain_stage_result tables have foreign key constraints on each other which sometimes doesn't allow to delete any of the corrupted rows. This type of issues can be solved by temporarily dropping the constraints and manually deleting the rows.

Is it possible to predict DB corruption cases and prevent them before they occur? Is it possible to somehow change the Bamboo database design and have Bamboo to automatically find and clean its DB?
fields.summary: Corrupted Database constraint violation problems

Error when deleting plan The DELETE statement conflicted with the REFERENCE constraint "FKEC405ED86EAFB613". The conflict occurred in database "testowa", table "dbo.BRS_CONSUMED_SUBSCRIPTION", column 'ARTIFACT_LINK_ID'.

fields.description:
I would like to re-commend that Bamboo should have the functionality to create build  dependencies  for the build running on different bamboo instances.

I would like to suggest this because our Build systems run on 2 different Bamboo instances and there is no mechanism where we can create dependency between the builds running on 2 different bamboo instances.
We can create a dependency between the build running on same instances of the Bamboo but this dependency feature is not available when we want to create a dependency between builds running on 2 different Bamboo instances. 

I believe, each Bamboo instances should expose some web service through which you can interact between the instances and also help us in dependency management also.

These web service can help us in serving other functions also.
fields.summary: Bamboo should have the functionality to create the depenency between the builds running on different Bamboo instances.

fields.description:

It will be great if there was an option to configure this behaviour and to allow to start dependent plans if all stages, including the manual ones, have completed.
fields.summary: Add ability to only start a dependent build if all manual stages have completed

fields.description:
I wrote a task module for Bamboo that takes an Atlassian Plugin jar built by Bamboo and installs it in a remote Confluence or JIRA instance (using UPM) - https://plugins.atlassian.com/plugin/details/602870

The task requires that the parent job must have an artifact dependency from an earlier stage that points to the plugin jar that is to be installed into the remote instance.

The configuration screen for the task allows the user to select the desired artifact from the list of artifact dependencies.

!^artifact_config.png!

Since upgrading my plugin to be a plugins-2 plugin, the config screen is no longer able to be loaded. Bamboo generates the inner exception:

{noformat}
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] Caused by: 
	org.springframework.beans.factory.UnsatisfiedDependencyException: 
		Error creating bean with name 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.confdeploy.AutoDeployConfigurator': 
			Unsatisfied dependency expressed through constructor argument with index 1 of type [com.atlassian.bamboo.plan.artifact.ArtifactSubscriptionManager]: 
				No unique bean of type [com.atlassian.bamboo.plan.artifact.ArtifactSubscriptionManager] is defined: expected at least 1 matching bean 
{noformat}

It would be great if the ArtifactSubscriptionManager bean was accessible to plugins, or an alternative means for selecting an artifact was provided.
fields.summary: artifactSubscriptionManager bean should be available to task plugins

fields.description:
Currently, if the user setup new Bamboo instance and try to specify the wrong file to import on the first attempt it will throw same error on the following attempt.

*Steps to replicate the problem:*
# Setup a new Bamboo instance 
# Reach to the import file UI
# Specify a wrong file to import (you will see the exception in UI)
# Click on back button in the browser 
# Specify the right file to import(you will see the same exception in the UI and the previous importing)

Workaround is to restart the instance.
fields.summary: Importing file failed when user try to import the right file on second attempt

*Steps to reproduce:*
* Create a Maven project in directory "sub" underneath a top-level directory "top"
* Add a plan with a Maven job to build it, specifying the working sub directory as "top"
* Enable Clover automatic integration
* Clover results are not collected

*Workaround:*
* Disable Clover autointegration
* manually specify the glob for clover.xml as top/target/site/clover/**/clover.xml
* Edit the "Clover Report (System)" artefact defintion's location to be top/target/site/clover/**/*.*

fields.description:
In Bamboo, when using the Atlassian Bamboo SCP Plugin as a Task in a build, I enter the hostname, username, password, etc. for the remote SCP connection. It works fine, however, reviewing the Bamboo database schema, it seems these configuration details are stored in the database table/field :  BUILD_DEFINITION.XML_DEFINITION_DATA. For the matching records for my build, I noticed the XML stores the following text : 

<taskDefinition>
      <id>3</id>
      <userDescription>Copy My WAR File To Remote Server </userDescription>
      <pluginKey>com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-scp-plugin:test</pluginKey>
      <finalising>false</finalising>
      <rootDirectoryType>INHERITED</rootDirectoryType>
      <repositoryDefiningWorkingDir>-1</repositoryDefiningWorkingDir>
      <config>
        <item>
          <key>password</key>
          <value>FAKE-PASSWORD</value>
        </item> 
 .... the rest removed for brevity.....

In this definition, the actual value of the password (in this example FAKE-PASSWORD) is actually visible in PLAINTEXT.

Can this should be modified to store an encrypted or hashed value?

Perhaps you can follow the same model as storing VCS repository credentials already used by Bamboo. For my VCS repo definition, which I located in the database at the following table/field : VCS_LOCATION.XML_DEFINITION_DATA the value for my VCS repo as an XML snippet with the password value encoded or encrypted in some manner. Perhaps this same mechanism can be used to encrypted the SCP remote host password?
fields.summary: Modify the Atlassian Bamboo SCP Plugin to Store SCP password as hashed or encrypted
JGit's HTTP and FTP transfer protocol aren't initialized on time for registration

fields.description:
In Bamboo 3.4 it isn't possible to configure build labeller plugin per plan as the documentation suggests; http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+Automatic+Labelling+of+Job+Build+Results

The build labeller plugin is configurable on per job basis:
http://screencast.com/t/0UVOFw5oPwi

We should update the [screenshot on CAC|http://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/229837908/bamboo_configurejob-postactions.png?version=1&modificationDate=1297149277847] to reflect this.
fields.summary: Update post-build labeller documentation

fields.description:
It seems that credentials provided for source checkout in the GitHub repository configuration aren't persisted.
The plugin we develop depends on the Git plugin as we perform different SCM operations.
When we try to fetch the repository credentials via:
{code}
repository.toConfiguration().getString("repository.github.username", "")
repository.toConfiguration().getString("repository.github.password", "")
{code}
Empty strings are returned.
Has the API been modified?
fields.summary: GitHub repository configuration doesn't persist credentials

fields.description: Please create the missing pages for Bamboo releases similar to [this one|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Changes%20for%20Bamboo%203.1].
fields.summary: Detailed documentation is missing for Bamboo changes after version 3.1.

fields.description:
Process creation is expensive (especially on Windows) and this is done for each polled plan. It's enough if this information is cached and refreshed every ~5 minutes (when the binary was present the last time. more often if it wasn't).
Or maybe it's possible to detect the (non)existence of Hg command during the actual CD (hg id) run?
fields.summary: Mercurial plugin should not check for hg binary existence every time change detection is run

fields.description:
When reviewing the permissions / notifications of a plan, it would be great to display next to a user id it's presentation name (e.g. label).

In my case, the user ids look like a123456 and one can't easily know who's behind the number.

Currently: a123456

Nicer display: a123456 (John Doe)
fields.summary: Display the presentation name of a user next to its id

fields.description:
When configuring the plan's notifications, one can notify different type of recipients: user, group, email address, IM address, committers & watchers.

It would be great to add another type of recipient: "launcher" or "triggerer" representing the person manually triggering a plan.

When a plan is only manual (e.g. manually triggered) and when several people can trigger this plan, we can't at the moment only notify the person who triggered the plan, we have to explicitly list all the possible "triggerers" thus notifying more people than needed.

Note: In my case, the plan above is *not* a CI plan, it's a deployment plan for which the "committers" recipient type doesn't make sense.
fields.summary: Add possibility to notify the person who triggered the plan

fields.description:
'Quarantine' tests help test driven development.

Currently it is reactive and not ideal - eg to quarantine each test it must first fail and then you can quarantine it.

To aid in test driven development, we will add a command '#QuarantineNewFailingTests'
which can be put in a commit message. If Bamboo detects this in the commit message that triggered a build, it will automatically quarantine all new tests that fail.

Other features may be added after dogfooding/release depending on feedback
fields.summary: Add some support for test driven development in tandem with quarantine
